headline: Big Tech's legal battles: What to watch for in 2025
summary: The US government spent much of 2024 cracking down on tech giants like Google (GOOGL, GOOG), Apple (AAPL), and Meta (META). The efforts started under former President Trump and then carried over into President Biden’s administration. Yahoo Finance senior legal reporter Alexis Keenan appears on Market Domination to discuss key events, including the DOJ's victory in its antitrust case against Google and what to watch for in 2025 as Trump takes office again.  To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime here. This post was written by Josh Lynch

headline: Apple investors may want to brace for a sell-off
summary: Apple (AAPL) shares are up about 8% over the past month. But BTIG chief market technician Jonathan Krinsky is warning investors about a potential sell-off in the stock. Krinsky notes that when Apple has posted five straight weeks of gains of more than 2%, the stock tends to fall over the following six weeks. Morning Brief Hosts Brad Smith and Brian Sozzi discuss the call in the video above. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here. This post was written by Stephanie Mikulich.

headline: Mag 7 is turning to 'lag 7': How to play tech in 2025
summary: Piper Sandler managing director and chief market technician Craig Johnson joins Josh Lipton on Market Domination. He suggests that, although stocks like Apple are trending upward, the "Magnificent Seven" — which comprises Nvidia (NVDA), Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL), Tesla (TSLA), Microsoft (MSFT), Amazon (AMZN), Meta (META), and Apple (AAPL) — may become the "lag seven" in 2025 as "the relative performance has not been nearly as strong." Johnson shares his strategy for navigating the shifting tech landscape in the coming year. "I would rather see investors — and I suspect this will happen as you get into early 2025 — taking some, not all, but some of their profits out of those larger cap stocks, reducing those positions, and then again, recognizing some of those gains that they may not have wanted to recognize in 2024 and [shifting] down cap, looking at stocks like Twilio (TWLO)." He also highlights Robinhood (HOOD) as an opportunity for investors, given the "more friendly crypto policy from the new administration." Johnson advises viewers not to forget optical companies, like Coherent (COHR), which "could be a better place to put some money to work." To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here. This post was written by Naomi Buchanan.

headline: Wedbush raises Apple price target to Street-high of $325
summary: Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives raised the firm’s price target on Apple (AAPL) to Street-High of $325 from $300 and keeps an Outperform rating on the shares. The firm believes Apple is heading into a multi-year AI-driven iPhone upgrade cycle, which is still being underestimated by the Street. Furthermore, Wedbush sees a growth catalyst from a new multi-billion annual services revenue stream from apps built around AI, along with catalyzing iPhone upgrades across the board over the next 12 to 18 month

headline: Apple seeks to participate in Google’s U.S. antitrust trial, Reuters says
summary: Apple (AAPL) has asked to participate in Google’s (GOOGL) U.S. antitrust trial over online search, arguing it cannot rely on Google to defend revenue-sharing arguments that send the iPhone maker billions of dollars each year for making Google the default engine on its phones, Jody Godoy of Reuters reports. Apple does not plan to build its own search engine and made $20B from its agreement with Google in 2022 alone. Apple wants to call witnesses to testify at an April trial. Published first on Th

headline: Is Berkshire Hathaway a Millionaire Maker?
summary: Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE: BRK.A) (NYSE: BRK.B) has minted many millionaires during the past six decades.  If you had invested $10,000 in Berkshire on May 10, 1965 -- the day Warren Buffett's investment fund took full control of the struggling textile maker -- your investment would be worth a whopping $381.9 million today.  Under Buffett, Berkshire liquidated its textile business, acquired insurance and energy companies, and expanded into other industries.
